abstract_summ: The number of patients infected in Italy since 20 February 2020 has closely followed an exponential trend, challenging our universal-coverage public healthcare system especially in terms of the availability of intensive care unit (ICU) beds, healthcare providers, and blood products (1,2).The impact of the current pandemic on the transplant community has been profound, with allocation of resources challenging both the donor and recipient processes.High mortality reports in transplant patients have created anxiety among some community practitioners as evidence as to why transplants should not be performed at this time, contrary to the recommendations from multiple transplant organizations.With shelter‐in‐place orders, outpatient clinics transitioned to telemedicine, and the threat of hospitals being overrun with COVID‐19 patients, liver transplant programs have been faced with the challenge of balancing patient and staff safety while operating in a resource limited environment.With the aid of Cloud Clinic service and telemedicine care, transplant patients could be regularly followed up and get medical consultation online.Simultaneously, two reports have highlighted the collapse of organ transplantation figures in several countries such as France (91%), the US (51%) and Spain (87%), mainly due to a reduction in the number of transplants from deceased donors.
